awd_titl_txt: Biology and Environmental Science Scholars Program to Support Achievement and Persistence in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, this project will support high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need at Chaminade University of Honolulu. Throughout its five years of funding, this project will provide 18 scholarships to students who are pursuing bachelor's degrees in Biology or Environmental Science. This project will provide these Scholars with culturally relevant STEM education around the theme of island resilience and sustainability and support their academic achievement and persistence in STEM. The project aims to develop a cohort of graduates who are prepared to enter the workforce in STEM disciplines connected to regional needs.

The goals of the project are to: 1) mitigate students' financial and academic barriers to STEM participation; 2) acknowledge and address cultural barriers to students' STEM participation; and 3) develop and evaluate new curricular and extracurricular activities that reflect students' needs, challenges, strengths, and cultural expectations. The knowledge gained through this project will enhance understanding of culturally-grounded curricular and academic support approaches to enhance student success. Faculty mentors will provide Scholars with academic support, life coaching, and advocacy. Scholars will participate in academic enrichment activities including tutoring, intensive advising, academic monitoring, academic crisis mitigation, and cohort learning communities. Scholars will have research internship opportunities focused on water sustainability. The project will develop activities to engage Scholars' families and connect to the community; these activities will be designed to decrease 'outsider status' and increase Scholars' sense of belonging within higher education and STEM careers. To support these goals, the project will redesign Biology and Environmental Science courses and pilot a novel 'mountain-to-ocean' four-year, culturally-based curriculum designed to increase retention, performance, cultural identity, and self-efficacy. This project will generate knowledge about student outcomes related to: (1) increasing the cultural relevance of the four-year degree process; (b) implementing and assessing blended indigenous and Western science approaches; and (c) maintaining connections to place and culture. This project aims to implement culturally-relevant, island-focused STEM educational experiences and foster collaborations among major stakeholders that include STEM faculty, campus administrators, and community leaders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF S-STEM `Inana (Hawaiian: Spark) grant at Chaminade University of Honolulu (CUH) has successfully advanced its overarching goal of transforming STEM education for high-talent, low-income students from Hawai‘i and the Pacific region. Through direct financial support, culturally responsive academic programming, and innovative curriculum enhancements, the program has mitigated financial barriers and created a replicable model for strengthening the regional STEM workforce. The program awarded four-year scholarships to 20 students pursuing Biology and Environmental Science degrees, ensuring that economic hardship did not hinder access to higher education. The grant  recruited scholars who reflect the geography of Hawai‘i and the Pacific, with over 90% of participants coming from public high schools and rural or remote island communities.

By deploying Academic Navigators—faculty and staff trained to provide holistic support—the initiative enhanced student retention, offering culturally anchored mentorship, family engagement, and structured research experiences aligned with island resilience and sustainability. A key achievement of the grant has been the development and validation of a high-impact, culturally integrated educational model that has strengthened students' academic trajectories and workforce readiness. The implementation of the Mauka-to-Makai meta-curriculum—an innovative framework that integrates traditional Hawaiian concepts into STEM education—provided students with a road map to STEM success that is relevant to their community and culture. Experiential learning opportunities have built students' career readiness and competitiveness, including real-world problem-solving in research and employer-sponsored internships.

The program’s success is underscored by the nearly 100% graduation rate of students who completed the program and minimal attrition, which primarily reflected non-academic factors. Scholars completed their degrees with competitive academic records in terms of GPA, with 14 graduates earning 17 degrees and seven minors to date. Graduates have transitioned into diverse roles, including environmental consulting, conservation research, legislative policy analysis, and graduate studies in biomedical sciences and data analytics. The program’s structured internships, research fellowships, and professional development workshops have further equipped students with competitive portfolios, positioning them for employment in critical STEM sectors that support regional innovation, economic diversification, resilience, and security. Beyond individual student success, the initiative has strengthened Chaminade's institutional capacity for STEM education, fostering interdisciplinary collaboration and attracting additional funding for research and workforce development.

 


Last Modified: 03/14/2025
Modified by: Helen Cathryn Turner
